detail.content: Visual Citizenship: Belonging through the Lens of Human Rights : Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content          < back        Visual Citizenship: Belonging through the Lens of Human Rights  VISUAL CITIZENSHIP As newspapers and magazines falter, losing their financial footing and overwhelmed by competing online resources, documentary photographers have increasingly sought a more independent approach. Rather than relying on mainstream media to present their own points of view in a credible way, they are coming up with a variety of new strategies—books, exhibitions, postcards, multimedia, facilitating the work of local photographers, etc.—finding that the viewers they reach may respond differently, and sometimes more deeply, to work done outside the warp speed of the 24-hour news cycle. This is not a completely new phenomenon—photographers such as Don McCullin and Philip Jones Griffiths made devastating comments on the Vietnam War, for example, via books that they had published—but in these complex and chaotic times, where good and evil are not always easy to separate, photographers have found it not only useful but necessary to invest in working methods that allow for complexity, emphasize the actuality of their subjects, engage readers more fully, and assert their own responsibility as witnesses and fellow citizens. The work exhibited here from the Tisch School of the Art’s Department of Photography & Imaging’s students, alumni and faculty, reflect a more nuanced view of recent events and ongoing situations. Jessica Ingram ’s A Civil Rights Memorial makes evident how the secular is so easily allowed to override the sacred, restoring our memory of those victimized by racism; Joseph Rodriguez ’s Still Here: Stories After Katrina , contests the mainstream focus on the spectacular with the enduring, emphasizing individual will; Robert Sukrachand ’s 74th and Roosevelt affirms the individuals and their histories lost in the generic label of “homeless”; Peter Lucas ’s work on Viva Favela in Brazil embraces self-identification as a powerful human right; and Alan Chin ’s conflicting readings of Chinese society through his own search for self weave the personal and idiosyncratic into the simplified public in Hollow Wealth: The Chasm Between Money and People in China . The work by professors Erika deVries and Lorie Novak with New York high school students under the umbrella of the Community Collaborations program furthers a sense that what can be taught must be shared, and the lens of looking points in multiple directions, and not only physically. In the histories of photography it is often the subject who is rendered paradoxically invisible, denied agency. Hopefully in this work it is not only the subjects who emerge, but the citizenship of both viewers and photographers who, rather than voyeurs, prefer to be counted among those who exercise their obligations to their fellow human beings. Study Abroad Summer High School Summer in New York City Programs for Visiting Students Open Arts Minors Blog Events Newsletters Videos Admin & Faculty Alumni Contact Us  home > Special Programs        Through the Documentary Lens: Civil Rights in America  OART-UT.1561 Lecture 4 Credits Instructor(s): Aviva Slesin This course is designed for students with an interest in exploring the Civil Rights Movement of 20th-century America through viewing and discussing documentaries. While the struggle for civil rights began early in American history, the course mostly focuses on the black Civil Rights movement with an emphasis on the period from 1954 through 1966. By focusing on this time period, which was reported and chronicled by the television/film media, the course covers different perspectives as well as provides insights about both the subject matter contained in the films and the techniques and skills of good documentary filmmaking. Through weekly screenings of films, class discussions, and invited guest speakers, students learn about the evolution of the documentary genre as a means of better understanding history, and students gain knowledge about the historical/political/cultural milestones and the heroes of the movement. Check Albert for course schedule. Slesin, Aviva: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Special Programs What Is Special Programs? Study Abroad Summer High School Summer in New York City Programs for Visiting Students Open Arts Minors Blog Events Newsletters Videos Admin & Faculty Alumni Contact Us  home > Special Programs          Special Programs   Slesin, Aviva Teacher, Open Arts Email: aviva.slesin@nyu.edu  Courses Master Class in Documentary: Director's Series Through the Documentary Lens: Civil Rights Through the Documentary Lens: Contemporary Art Through the Documentary Lens: Human Rights Biography Aviva  Slesin is an accomplished, award-winning documentary filmmaker. She won an  Academy Award in 1988 for her feature-length film, The Ten Year Lunch: The Wit  and Legend of the Algonquin Round Table . The film screened at Sundance and  many other film festivals around the world and aired on American Masters/PBS.  Her other films include Voices in Celebration , a documentary that  celebrated the 50th anniversary of the National Gallery of Art, Directed by  William Wyler , a biography of the late Hollywood director which also  screened at Sundance and was nominated for an Emmy and, more recently, Secret  Lives: Hidden Children and Their Rescuers During World War II , which was  based on her own experience as a “hidden child” in Lithuania. This documentary  was nominated for two Emmys in 2004, aired on HBO/Cinemax, was a critic’s  pick of the New York Times and was named one of the best 10 documentaries  of the year by Andrew Sarris. She also produced and directed many short films  for Saturday Night Live , HBO’s Real Sex , CTW’s Sesame Street ,  John Hockenberry’s Edgewise, Comedy Central’s HA! and, most recently,   Talk About Art , for the National Gallery of Art. A selection of her  work, The Long and Short of It , was screened as a special program  at The Sundance Film Festival.  Ms.  Slesin began her career as a film editor on such films as Making Television  Dance , about choreographer Twyla Tharp, The Rutles , a Beatles satire  written and directed by Monty Python’s Eric Idle and The Other Half of the Sky: A China Memoir , produced by Shirley MacLaine.           She  is the president of Aviva Films NY and a member of the Academy of Motion  Picture Arts and Sciences as well as the Directors Guild of America.
